pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [01a8057c32](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22076/commits/01a8057c32f6f210c28b7a2b7a930b55dfc964db)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ delabFinsetFilter`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This is nice, but I wonder if we can make it slightly nicer. Currently, this occurs:
```
import Mathlib

variable {Œ± : Type*} [Fintype Œ±] {p : Œ± ‚Üí Prop} {s : Finset Œ±} {a : Œ±}
    [DecidablePred p] [DecidableEq Œ±]

#check ({x | p x} : Finset Œ±) -- works
#check ({x ‚àà s | p x}) -- works
#check ({x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ±) -- {x ‚àà {a}·∂ú | p x} : Finset Œ±
#check ({x ‚àâ s | p x}) -- {x ‚àà s·∂ú | p x} : Finset Œ±
```
I understand what's going on ((3) and (4) are special cases of (2), and the logic for (2) dictates the resulting syntax). However, I wonder if you could add some additional logic / matching to handle those special cases (when `s := {a}·∂ú` or when `s := s·∂ú`).

Do so wouldn't make it round trip, but it would at least mean the delaborator is providing syntax for the nicest notation in each case.

I can't get it to work. Here's my best attempt (put it at the end of `Data.Finset.BooleanAlgebra`). Somehow `trySynthInstance q(DecidableEq $Œ±)` fails even though `DecidableEq Œ±` is in context.

```
namespace Mathlib.Meta
open Lean Elab Term Meta Batteries.ExtendedBinder Parser.Term PrettyPrinter.Delaborator SubExpr Qq

/-- Delaborator for `Finset.filter`. The `pp.funBinderTypes` option controls whether
to show the domain type when the filter is over `Finset.univ`. -/
@[app_delab Finset.filter] def delabFinsetFilter : Delab :=
  whenPPOption getPPNotation do
  let ppDomain ‚Üê getPPOption getPPFunBinderTypes
  let #[_, p, _, s] := (‚Üê getExpr).getAppArgs | failure
  guard p.isLambda
  let i ‚Üê withNaryArg 1 <| withBindingBodyUnusedName fun i => pure (‚ü®i‚ü© : Ident)
  let p ‚Üê withNaryArg 1 <| withBindingBody i.getId do
    let p ‚Üê delab
    return p
  let ‚ü®.succ u, ~q(Finset $Œ±), s‚ü© ‚Üê inferTypeQ s | failure
  logInfo "hi"
  match s with
  | ~q(@Finset.univ _ $inst) =>
    if ppDomain then
      let ty ‚Üê withNaryArg 0 delab
      `({$i:ident : $ty | $p})
    else
      `({$i:ident | $p})
  | s =>
    match ‚Üê trySynthInstanceQ q(DecidableEq $Œ±), ‚Üê trySynthInstanceQ q(Fintype $Œ±) with
    | .some _, .some _ =>
      match s with
      | ~q({$a}·∂ú) =>
        let a ‚Üê withNaryArg 3 <| withNaryArg 2 <| withNaryArg 3 delab
        `({$i:ident ‚â† $a | $p})
      | ~q($s) =>
        let t ‚Üê withNaryArg 3 <| withNaryArg 2 delab
        `({$i:ident ‚àâ $t | $p})
      | _ =>
        let t ‚Üê withNaryArg 3 delab
        `({$i:ident ‚àà $t | $p})
    | _, _ =>
      let t ‚Üê withNaryArg 3 delab
      `({$i:ident ‚àà $t | $p})

end Mathlib.Meta
```

Thanks for the PR!

maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Thanks!

bors d+

Maybe you could also add Jireh's examples as tests somewhere? Here they are again (I had to add two instances, not sure if that's just because of missing imports in my example file):

```lean
variable {Œ± : Type*} [Fintype Œ±] {p : Œ± ‚Üí Prop} {s : Finset Œ±} {a : Œ±}
    [DecidablePred p] [DecidableEq Œ±] [Singleton Œ± (Finset Œ±)] [HasCompl (Finset Œ±)]

/-- info: {x | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x | p x} : Finset Œ±)

/-- info: {x ‚àà s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x ‚àà s | p x})

/-- info: {x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ±) -- {x ‚àà {a}·∂ú | p x} : Finset Œ±

/-- info: {x ‚àâ s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x ‚àâ s | p x})

/-- info: {x : Œ± | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x | p x} : Finset Œ±)

/-- info: {x ‚àà s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x ‚àà s | p x})

/-- info: {x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ±)

/-- info: {x ‚àâ s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x ‚àâ s | p x})
```

Maybe you could also add Jireh's examples as tests somewhere? Here they are again (I had to add two instances, not sure if that's just because of missing imports in my example file):

```lean
variable {Œ± : Type*} [Fintype Œ±] {p : Œ± ‚Üí Prop} {s : Finset Œ±} {a : Œ±}
    [DecidablePred p] [DecidableEq Œ±] [Singleton Œ± (Finset Œ±)] [HasCompl (Finset Œ±)]

/-- info: {x | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x | p x} : Finset Œ±)

/-- info: {x ‚àà s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x ‚àà s | p x})

/-- info: {x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ±) -- {x ‚àà {a}·∂ú | p x} : Finset Œ±

/-- info: {x ‚àâ s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
#check ({x ‚àâ s | p x})

/-- info: {x : Œ± | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x | p x} : Finset Œ±)

/-- info: {x ‚àà s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x ‚àà s | p x})

/-- info: {x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ±)

/-- info: {x ‚àâ s | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in
set_option pp.funBinderTypes true in
#check ({x ‚àâ s | p x})
```

Thanks!

bors d+
I'd say that this should be controlled by the funBinderTypes option, since that's the one which controls the same without this delaborator.
Yeah I think you're right. I'm also modifying the existing delaborators for `Finset.sum`/`Finset.prod` to use it

```suggestion
  -- check if `t` is of the form `s‚ÇÄ·∂ú`, in which case we display `x ‚àâ s‚ÇÄ` instead
  else if t.isAppOfArity ``HasCompl.compl 3 then
    let #[_, _, s‚ÇÄ] := t.getAppArgs | failure
    -- if `s‚ÇÄ` is a singleton, we can even use the notation `x ‚â† a`
    if s‚ÇÄ.isAppOfArity ``Singleton.singleton 4 then
      let t ‚Üê withNaryArg 3 <| withNaryArg 2 <| withNaryArg 3 delab
      `({$i:ident ‚â† $t | $p})
    else
      let t ‚Üê withNaryArg 3 <| withNaryArg 2 delab
      `({$i:ident ‚àâ $t | $p})
  else
    let t ‚Üê withNaryArg 3 delab
    `({$i:ident ‚àà $t | $p})
```

I think this does what Jireh suggested :)

```suggestion
  let p ‚Üê withNaryArg 1 <| withBindingBody i.getId delab
```

```suggestion
  let i ‚Üê withNaryArg 1 <| withBindingBodyUnusedName (pure ‚ü®¬∑‚ü©)
```
(personal preference, optional!)

```suggestion
    if (‚Üê getPPOption getPPFunBinderTypes) then
```
or moving the `let ppDomain` here:
```suggestion
    let ppDomain ‚Üê getPPOption getPPFunBinderTypes
    if ppDomain then
```

```suggestion
#check ({x ‚â† a | p x} : Finset Œ±)
```

pullRequest.title: feat: delaborator for finset builder notation

Do so wouldn't make it round trip, but it would at least mean the delaborator is providing syntax for the nicest notation in each case.

to show the domain type when the filter is over `Finset.univ`. -/
@[app_delab Finset.filter] def delabFinsetFilter : Delab :=
  whenPPOption getPPNotation do

  let #[_, p, _, s] := (‚Üê getExpr).getAppArgs | failure
  guard p.isLambda
  let i ‚Üê withNaryArg 1 <| withBindingBodyUnusedName fun i => pure (‚ü®i‚ü© : Ident)
  let p ‚Üê withNaryArg 1 <| withBindingBody i.getId do

    return p

end Mathlib.Meta

/-- info: {x | p x} : Finset Œ± -/
#guard_msgs in

Thanks for the PR!
